dealProcess.overview: The MIQ deal process follows 7 key stages from initial scoping through evaluation.

stages.name: Scoping
stages.description: Initial definition of customer needs and potential solutions
stages.details: Deal scoping is the critical first stage of our deal process where we define what the customer needs and how we can help them. It involves customer analysis, needs assessment, preliminary solution design, and value proposition definition.
processSteps: Complete the Deal Scoping Request form in the system
Document all findings in the Deal Scoping Document
Receive approval to proceed to formal submission
stages.tips: The more detailed your scoping information, the faster your deal can progress through later stages.

stages.name: Submission
stages.description: Formal documentation of all deal details
stages.details: The deal submission stage formalizes your opportunity with complete details needed for review and approval.
documentation: Price Quote and Discount Approval Forms
processSteps: Log into the Deal Management System
Complete all required fields in the submission form
stages.timeline: Submission process takes 15-30 minutes with all documentation ready
bestPractices: Be specific about special terms or requirements
Include clear business justification for any non-standard requests

stages.name: Review & Approval
stages.description: Deal desk assessment and approval based on financial metrics
stages.details: The Review & Approval stage involves multiple stakeholders reviewing the deal terms, pricing, legal considerations, and strategic fit.

approvalLevels.authority: Standard deals up to $250K, non-standard terms

stages.escalationProcess: If a deal is urgent, mark as 'High Priority' in the system and notify your manager directly.

stages.name: Negotiation
stages.details: During Negotiation, any requested changes from either party are discussed and terms are finalized.
keyConsiderations: Pricing boundaries and minimum acceptable terms
Service level agreements and support provisions
bestPractices: Maintain clear communication between all stakeholders
Focus on value creation over price concessions
Address technical concerns with solution engineering
Be clear about approval requirements for changes
stages.timeline: Varies based on complexity - typically 1-2 weeks

stages.name: Contracting
stages.details: The Contracting stage involves generating legal documents, collecting signatures, and finalizing the formal agreement.
processSteps: Generate contract documents from approved deal terms
Send documents to customer for signature
Counter-sign and return fully executed documents
Store final documentation in the contract management system
stages.timeline: 3-5 business days for standard agreements, 1-2 weeks for complex deals

stages.name: Implementation
stages.details: Implementation covers technical setup, customer training, and initial service delivery.
stages.timeline: Varies by deal complexity - 2-6 weeks typical

stages.name: Evaluation
stages.details: The Evaluation stage involves measuring deal performance against targets and identifying optimization opportunities.
reviewProcess: Pre-renewal planning (3-6 months before term end)

incentivePrograms.overview: MIQ offers various incentive programs to drive customer success and growth.

types.name: Financial Incentives
types.description: Monetary benefits that reduce overall costs
types.eligibility: Typically requires minimum annual commitment of $50K and contract term of 12+ months.
types.approvalProcess: Requires financial review and manager approval, with higher tiers needing director-level sign-off.

types.name: Product Incentives
types.eligibility: Strategic accounts with annual commitment of $100K+ with multi-year agreements.
types.approvalProcess: Requires product team assessment and director approval.

types.name: Resource Incentives
types.eligibility: Available for enterprise accounts with complex implementation needs.
types.approvalProcess: Requires resource planning approval and operations review.

dealStructures.name: Tiered Commit
dealStructures.description: Multiple spending thresholds with increasing incentives at each level
dealStructures.bestFor: Growing accounts with increasing usage patterns
dealStructures.example: Tier 1: $100K (2% rebate), Tier 2: $250K (3% rebate), Tier 3: $500K (5% rebate)
considerations: More complex to track and report

dealStructures.name: Flat Commit
dealStructures.description: Single spending threshold with fixed incentive rate
dealStructures.example: $500K annual commitment with fixed 4% rebate on all spend
considerations: May leave value on table for high-growth accounts

levels.title: Manager
levels.approvalThreshold: Standard incentives up to 5% on deals under $100K

levels.title: Director
levels.approvalThreshold: Incentives up to 10% on deals under $500K

levels.title: VP
levels.approvalThreshold: Incentives up to 15% on deals under $1M

levels.title: SVP/C-Level
levels.approvalThreshold: Any incentives on deals over $1M or above 15%

documentationRequirements.overview: Proper documentation is essential for efficient deal processing and approval.

requiredDocuments.name: Deal Submission Form
requiredDocuments.purpose: Captures all essential deal details including customer information, deal structure, and financial terms
requiredDocuments.format: Online form in Deal Management System
requiredDocuments.tips: Complete all fields, even if some are marked optional, for faster processing.

requiredDocuments.name: Customer Requirements Document
requiredDocuments.purpose: Details specific customer needs, technical requirements, and success criteria
requiredDocuments.template: Available in Resource Center > Templates > Customer Requirements

requiredDocuments.name: Statement of Work
requiredDocuments.purpose: Defines specific deliverables, timeline, resources, and success criteria for service components
requiredDocuments.required: Only for deals with service components
requiredDocuments.format: PDF or Word document using company template
requiredDocuments.template: Available in Resource Center > Templates > SOW

requiredDocuments.name: Business Justification
requiredDocuments.purpose: Explains rationale for non-standard terms, pricing exceptions, or special requirements
requiredDocuments.format: Brief document (1-2 pages) outlining business case
requiredDocuments.tips: Focus on strategic value, competitive situation, and long-term potential.

requiredDocuments.name: Technical Specifications
requiredDocuments.purpose: Details technical implementation requirements, integrations, and customizations
requiredDocuments.format: Technical document with architecture diagrams if applicable
requiredDocuments.approvals: Requires technical team review before submission

bestPractices: Use the latest document templates from the Resource Center
Include detailed contact information for all stakeholders
Be specific about any special terms or requirements
Include competitive information when relevant to negotiations
Attach all supporting materials as separate files rather than embedded
Name files consistently with deal ID and document type
Ensure all financial information is accurate and consistent across documents

urgentDeals.definition: Deals requiring expedited processing due to valid business reasons
urgentDeals.limitations: Urgent process should be used sparingly and only for genuine business needs.

dealModifications.definition: Changes to existing deals already in the system
process: Complete modification form with changes and justification
dealModifications.approvalRequirements: Significant changes may require new approval process.
dealModifications.timeline: Minor modifications: 1-2 days; Major changes: follows standard approval timeline

faqs.question: What are the incentive thresholds?
faqs.answer: Deal incentives are calculated based on total deal value, contract length, and growth metrics. Standard deals have a 2% incentive, while strategic deals can qualify for up to 5% incentives with proper approval.

faqs.question: How are urgent deals handled?
faqs.answer: For urgent deals, follow these steps: 1) Mark as 'Urgent' in the submission form, 2) Add business justification explaining the urgency, 3) Notify your manager, and 4) Email deal-desk@example.com with the reference number. Urgent deals are typically reviewed within 24 hours.

faqs.question: What growth opportunities qualify for incentives?
faqs.answer: Growth opportunities that qualify for incentives include: expanding to new markets, increasing contract value by at least 20%, extending contract terms beyond 24 months, or adding new product lines to existing contracts.

faqs.question: What are the approval requirements?
faqs.answer: Discount approval follows a tiered process: up to 10% can be approved by team leads, 10-20% by managers, and anything over 20% requires director approval. All discounts must be documented with business justification.

faqs.question: How do I submit a new deal?
faqs.answer: To submit a new deal, navigate to the 'Submit Deal' page from the main menu. Fill out all required fields, attach any necessary documentation, and then click 'Submit for Review'. You'll receive a confirmation email with the deal reference number.
